results.title: S.O.S.: save our sons
results.creator_credit: Rebecca McLean, Elisa Argenzio and S O S Pictures Pty Ltd
results.brief_description: The gaoling of the ‘Fairlea Five’ was the first many Australians had heard of the Save our Sons movement; a group of women formed in the sixties to protest against the Vietnam War. S.O.S explores the motivation of this group of women, charting their progress from their unpopular beginnings in 1965, to the moratoriums and re-election of the Labour Party in 1972. The film uses interviews, original footage and news clippings to illustrate their strategies (both conventional and non-conventional), specific areas of protest (including anti-conscription and conscientious objecting), and their achievements over this time.

results.title: Russia in Europe
results.brief_description: A survey of European Russia, west of the Ural Mountains. Shows the topography, living conditions, agriculture, waterways and chief cities of this area including Yalta on the Black Sea. The Communist form of government is discussed briefly. Heavy industry has expanded under the five and seven year plans, but the standard of living is lower than in many Western countries.

results.title: Russia beneath the sputniks
results.brief_description: In 1957 the Soviet Union put the first satellite into space, and since then has achieved other spectacular “firsts” in space. But Soviet scientists are also tackling other problems of more immediate consequence to its 200 million population. The opening up of the frozen deserts of the Arctic Circle and the discovery of minerals there; the chemical compounding of foods; and the use of computers particularly in the field of hospital surgery and medical research are a part of the quiet revolution in progress behind the closed doors of the Soviet Union.

results.title: Rushing to sunshine (Seoul diaries)
results.brief_description: A sequel to Hoaas’ “Pyongyang diaries”, “Rushing to sunshine” continues the filmmaker’s personal diaristic exploration of the social and political realities of life in North and South Korea. Drawing on material she gathered over a two year period from March 1998 to March 2000, a period of great economic upheaval and social change in South Korea, Hoaas’ reflects on the country’s attempts at reconciliation with North Korea motivated by Kim Dae Jung’s ‘Sunshine Policy.’ Combining her personal insights with the stories of former political prisoners, student dissidents, academics and people on the street, Hoaas uncovers the uncomfortable paradoxes that face a society caught between the Government’s new open door policy and the remnants of a cold war anti-Communist mindset. In English and Korean with English subtitles.
